content.webTitle: Growing up, I was mortified by my allergies and eczema. I wish I knew I wasn't alone | Allayne Webster

fields.headline: Growing up, I was mortified by my allergies and eczema. I wish I knew I wasn't alone
fields.bodyText: I’m out to dinner with friends. The waitress approaches, and I cringe. Here it comes. I’m about to do The Speech. I point to my wrist, to my Medic Alert bracelet. “Can you let the chef know I’m allergic to …” – I rattle off a list of allergens and explain they can cause anaphylaxis. I joke that the restaurant doesn’t want an ambulance out front, that it’s bad for business. I don’t do it to be jovial. I do it to get my point across: My life is in your hands. You could kill me. Irritation flickers on the waitress’s face: “What was it again?” I point to the menu and explain what I think could be a safe option – minus the sauce. “Hang on. I’ll go check.” I apologise to my friends. They tell me it’s no trouble. The waitress returns; there’s a problem with my choice. We negotiate a different one. She goes back to the kitchen. I hold up everyone, yet again. I just want it to be over with. When my meal arrives, I sample some and wait. No tingling, no swelling, no itchiness. When I leave, I profusely thank the staff for their service; I thank them for not killing me. And so it goes with every social gathering at a restaurant, at a friend’s house, at anywhere food is served. Food is central to how we interact; we celebrate by breaking bread and clinking glasses. But for allergy sufferers, dining out is an anxiety-producing nightmare. Our first thought is not, “What would I like to eat?” But, “What won’t kill me?” Of course, when it comes to dietary restrictions, allergy sufferers aren’t alone. We are in the company of diabetics, vegans, vegetarians, the gluten or lactose intolerant, those with restrictions imposed by religion, those who simply hate mushrooms. But allergic folk are more troublesome. Menus don’t indicate safe choices for us, and there’s the added risk of cross-contamination, unwitting kitchen mix-ups or indifference. I also suffer from chronic atopic eczema. The two are separate conditions but they often come hand-in-hand. And if it’s tough for me as an adult, spare a thought for a child, or for the parent of a toddler with food allergies. I’ve suffered from eczema and allergies since the age of five. My condition has swung from barely there, to present but manageable, to actively impacting my quality of life, to life-threatening. There’s no consistency. It’s unpredictable, often from one hour to the next, and that’s what makes it hard to accept. Because the times you’re well, you’re asking, “What is it I’m doing right?” And the times you’re unwell, “What am I doing wrong?” You rarely get an answer to either. Severe eczema can feel like being eaten alive by a swarm of mosquitos. It can also feel like sunburn, except you’re burning from the inside out. You get tired and headachy, feel restless and on edge, and you’re acutely self-conscious of your appearance. Sleep doesn’t even bring peace. You scratch all night long. In short, it’s utterly exhausting. But what we don’t talk about is the mental strain. The resulting anxiety and depression, the impact on family and friends, the cost of simply trying to survive. Medicines, creams, lotions and potions, doctor appointments, gap fees. The costs add up economically and emotionally. Add to that a backdrop of a society obsessed with beauty, with correcting imperfections, and it becomes a recipe for self-loathing and despair. When I was a teenager I hated myself with a passion. I was mortified by my condition and I did everything I could to try to hide it – even if that meant putting myself at risk. Sometimes I did things to fit in, with the full knowledge I’d pay the price later. Resentment reigned supreme, and I was deeply jealous of anyone who was healthy. Why did I have to be the one? Excursions, a sleepover, summer camp – were not joyous occasions, but exercises in risk to be forward-planned and managed. I wish I had a book growing up which showed me I wasn’t alone. That’s why I wrote one. My book, Sensitive, isn’t just for those kids though; it’s also for those who want insight into their lives. I hope the hospitality industry reads it, because more often than not sufferers are placing their lives in the hands of complete strangers, praying they’ll be taken seriously. The alternative is to become a hermit – and who wants to live like that? But mostly I’ve written Sensitive for kids like me. For kids who feel ashamed, different, less-than. I want them to know they’re not alone and that the emotions they struggle with are legitimate and real. Putting on a brave face doesn’t always cut it. It’s OK to admit it sucks. • Sensitive, a YA book by Allayne Webster, is out now through UQP
